386                 quantity if outcome in outcome_set else stop_factor * quantity)
387                for outcome, quantity in self.items()
388            }
389        return icepool.Die(data)

Rerolls the given outcomes.

Arguments:
  • which: Selects which outcomes to reroll. Options:
    • A single outcome to reroll.
    • A collection of outcomes to reroll.
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be rerolled.
    • If not provided, the min outcome will be rerolled.
  • star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments before sending them to a callable which. If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function signature.
  • depth: The maximum number of times to reroll. If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
Returns:

A Die representing the reroll. If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.

def filter( self, which: Union[Callable[..., bool], Collection[+T_co]], /, *, star: bool | None = None, depth: int | None = None) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
391    def filter(self,
392               which: Callable[..., bool] | Collection[T_co],
393               /,
394               *,
395               star: bool | None = None,
396               depth: int | None = None) -> 'Die[T_co]':
397        """Rerolls until getting one of the given outcomes.
398
399        Essentially the complement of `reroll()`.
400
401        Args:
402            which: Selects which outcomes to reroll until. Options:
403                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
404                    should be accepted.
405                * A collection of outcomes to reroll until.
406            star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments
407                before sending them to a callable `which`.
408                If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function
409                signature.
410            depth: The maximum number of times to reroll.
411                If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
412
413        Returns:
414            A `Die` representing the reroll.
415            If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.
416        """
417
418        if callable(which):
419            if star is None:
420                star = guess_star(which, variadic=True)
421            if star:
422
423                not_outcomes = {
424                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
425                    if not which(*outcome)  # type: ignore
426                }
427            else:
428                not_outcomes = {
429                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if not which(outcome)
430                }
431        else:
432            not_outcomes = {
433                not_outcome for not_outcome in self.outcomes()
434                if not_outcome not in which
435            }
436        return self.reroll(not_outcomes, depth=depth)

Rerolls until getting one of the given outcomes.

Essentially the complement of reroll().

Arguments:
  • which: Selects which outcomes to reroll until. Options:
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be accepted.
    • A collection of outcomes to reroll until.
  • star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments before sending them to a callable which. If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function signature.
  • depth: The maximum number of times to reroll. If omitted, rerolls an unlimited number of times.
Returns:

A Die representing the reroll. If the reroll would never terminate, the result has no outcomes.

def truncate( self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
438    def truncate(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die[T_co]':
439        """Truncates the outcomes of this `Die` to the given range.
440
441        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
442        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.
443
444        This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range.
445        If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint,
446        use `clip()`.
447
448        Not to be confused with `trunc(die)`, which performs integer truncation
449        on each outcome.
450        """
451        if min_outcome is not None:
452            start = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), min_outcome)
453        else:
454            start = None
455        if max_outcome is not None:
456            stop = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), max_outcome)
457        else:
458            stop = None
459        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items()[start:stop]}
460        return icepool.Die(data)

Truncates the outcomes of this Die to the given range.

The endpoints are included in the result if applicable. If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be truncated.

This effectively rerolls outcomes outside the given range. If instead you want to replace those outcomes with the nearest endpoint, use clip().

Not to be confused with trunc(die), which performs integer truncation on each outcome.

def clip( self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
462    def clip(self, min_outcome=None, max_outcome=None) -> 'Die[T_co]':
463        """Clips the outcomes of this `Die` to the given values.
464
465        The endpoints are included in the result if applicable.
466        If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.
467
468        This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range;
469        the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range.
470        This will typically cause some quantity to bunch up at the endpoint.
471        If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use `truncate()`.
472        """
473        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
474        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
475            if min_outcome is not None and outcome <= min_outcome:
476                data[min_outcome] += quantity
477            elif max_outcome is not None and outcome >= max_outcome:
478                data[max_outcome] += quantity
479            else:
480                data[outcome] += quantity
481        return icepool.Die(data)

Clips the outcomes of this Die to the given values.

The endpoints are included in the result if applicable. If one of the arguments is not provided, that side will not be clipped.

This is not the same as rerolling outcomes beyond this range; the outcome is simply adjusted to fit within the range. This will typically cause some quantity to bunch up at the endpoint. If you want to reroll outcomes beyond this range, use truncate().

def set_range( self: icepool.Die[int], min_outcome: int | None = None, max_outcome: int | None = None) -> icepool.Die[int]: 
483    def set_range(self: 'Die[int]',
484                  min_outcome: int | None = None,
485                  max_outcome: int | None = None) -> 'Die[int]':
486        """Sets the outcomes of this `Die` to the given `int` range (inclusive).
487
488        This may remove outcomes (if they are not within the range)
489        and/or add zero-quantity outcomes (if they are in range but not present
490        in this `Die`).
491
492        Args:
493            min_outcome: The min outcome of the result.
494                If omitted, the min outcome of this `Die` will be used.
495            max_outcome: The max outcome of the result.
496                If omitted, the max outcome of this `Die` will be used.
497        """
498        if min_outcome is None:
499            min_outcome = self.min_outcome()
500        if max_outcome is None:
501            max_outcome = self.max_outcome()
502
503        return self.set_outcomes(range(min_outcome, max_outcome + 1))

Sets the outcomes of this Die to the given int range (inclusive).

This may remove outcomes (if they are not within the range) and/or add zero-quantity outcomes (if they are in range but not present in this Die).

Arguments:
  • min_outcome: The min outcome of the result. If omitted, the min outcome of this Die will be used.
  • max_outcome: The max outcome of the result. If omitted, the max outcome of this Die will be used.
def set_outcomes(self, outcomes: Iterable[+T_co]) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
505    def set_outcomes(self, outcomes: Iterable[T_co]) -> 'Die[T_co]':
506        """Sets the set of outcomes to the argument.
507
508        This may remove outcomes (if they are not present in the argument)
509        and/or add zero-quantity outcomes (if they are not present in this `Die`).
510        """
511        data = {x: self.quantity(x) for x in outcomes}
512        return icepool.Die(data)

Sets the set of outcomes to the argument.

This may remove outcomes (if they are not present in the argument) and/or add zero-quantity outcomes (if they are not present in this Die).

def trim(self) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
514    def trim(self) -> 'Die[T_co]':
515        """Removes all zero-quantity outcomes. """
516        data = {k: v for k, v in self.items() if v > 0}
517        return icepool.Die(data)

Removes all zero-quantity outcomes.

def map( self, repl: Union[Callable[..., Union[~U, icepool.Die[~U], icepool.RerollType, icepool.population.again.AgainExpression]], Mapping[+T_co, Union[~U, icepool.Die[~U], icepool.RerollType, icepool.population.again.AgainExpression]]], /, *, star: bool | None = None, repeat: int | None = 1, again_depth: int = 1, again_end: Union[~U, icepool.Die[~U], icepool.RerollType, NoneType] = None) -> icepool.Die[~U]: 
547    def map(
548            self,
549            repl:
550        'Callable[..., U | Die[U] | icepool.RerollType | icepool.AgainExpression] | Mapping[T_co, U | Die[U] | icepool.RerollType | icepool.AgainExpression]',
551            /,
552            *,
553            star: bool | None = None,
554            repeat: int | None = 1,
555            again_depth: int = 1,
556            again_end: 'U | Die[U] | icepool.RerollType | None' = None
557    ) -> 'Die[U]':
558        """Maps outcomes of the `Die` to other outcomes.
559
560        This is also useful for representing processes.
561
562        EXPERIMENTAL: `Again`, `again_depth`, and `again_end` can be used as the
563        `Die()` constructor. It is not advised to use these with `repeat` other
564        than 1.
565
566        Args:
567            repl: One of the following:
568                * A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
569                * A mapping from old outcomes to new outcomes.
570                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
571                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
572                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
573            star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments
574                before sending them to a callable `repl`.
575                If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function
576                signature.
577            repeat: This will be repeated with the same arguments on the
578                result this many times.
579
580                EXPERIMENTAL: If set to `None`, the result will be as if this
581                    were repeated an infinite number of times. In this case, the
582                    result will be in simplest form.
583            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
584            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
585
586        Returns:
587            The `Die` after the modification.
588        """
589        if repeat == 0:
590            # In this case, U and T_co better be equal.
591            return cast(Die[U], self)
592
593        # Convert to a single-argument function.
594        if callable(repl):
595            if star is None:
596                star = guess_star(repl, variadic=True)
597            if star:
598
599                def transition_function(outcome):
600                    return repl(*outcome)
601            else:
602
603                def transition_function(outcome):
604                    return repl(outcome)
605        else:
606            # repl is a mapping.
607            def transition_function(outcome):
608                if outcome in repl:
609                    return repl[outcome]
610                else:
611                    return outcome
612
613        if repeat is not None:
614            if repeat < 0:
615                raise ValueError('repeat cannot be negative.')
616            # T_co and U should be the same in this case.
617            result: 'Die[U]' = cast(Die[U], self)
618            for _ in range(repeat):
619                result = icepool.map(transition_function,
620                                     result,
621                                     again_depth=again_depth,
622                                     again_end=again_end)
623            return result
624        else:
625            # Infinite repeat.
626            # T_co and U should be the same in this case.
627            return icepool.population.markov_chain.absorbing_markov_chain(
628                cast(Die[U], self), transition_function)

Maps outcomes of the Die to other outcomes.

This is also useful for representing processes.

EXPERIMENTAL: Again, again_depth, and again_end can be used as the Die() constructor. It is not advised to use these with repeat other than 1.

Arguments:
  • repl: One of the following:
    • A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
    • A mapping from old outcomes to new outcomes. Unmapped old outcomes stay the same. The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes. The special value icepool.Reroll will reroll that old outcome.
  • star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments before sending them to a callable repl. If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function signature.

  • repeat: This will be repeated with the same arguments on the result this many times.

    EXPERIMENTAL: If set to None, the result will be as if this were repeated an infinite number of times. In this case, the result will be in simplest form.

  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
Returns:

The Die after the modification.

def map_and_time( self, repl: Union[Callable[..., Union[+T_co, icepool.Die[+T_co], icepool.RerollType]], Mapping[+T_co, Union[+T_co, icepool.Die[+T_co], icepool.RerollType]]], /, *, star: bool | None = None, repeat: int) -> icepool.Die[tuple[+T_co, int]]: 
630    def map_and_time(
631            self,
632            repl:
633        'Callable[..., T_co | Die[T_co] | icepool.RerollType] | Mapping[T_co, T_co | Die[T_co] | icepool.RerollType]',
634            /,
635            *,
636            star: bool | None = None,
637            repeat: int) -> 'Die[tuple[T_co, int]]':
638        """Maps outcomes of the `Die` to other outcomes, while also counting
639        timesteps.
640
641        This is useful for representing processes.
642
643        The outcomes of the result are  `(outcome, time)`, where `time` is the
644        number of repeats needed to reach an absorbing outcome (an outcome that
645        only leads to itself), or `repeat`, whichever is lesser.
646
647        This will return early if it reaches a fixed point.
648        Therefore, you can set `repeat` equal to the maximum number of
649        time you could possibly be interested in without worrying about
650        it causing extra computations after the fixed point.
651
652        EXPERIMENTAL: `Again`, `again_depth`, and `again_end` can be used as the
653        `Die()` constructor. It is not advised to use these with `repeat` other
654        than 1.
655
656        Args:
657            repl: One of the following:
658                * A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
659                * A mapping from old outcomes to new outcomes.
660                    Unmapped old outcomes stay the same.
661                The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes.
662                The special value `icepool.Reroll` will reroll that old outcome.
663            star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments
664                before sending them to a callable `repl`.
665                If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function
666                signature.
667            repeat: This will be repeated with the same arguments on the result
668                this many times.
669            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
670            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
671
672        Returns:
673            The `Die` after the modification.
674        """
675        # Convert to a single-argument function.
676        if callable(repl):
677            if star is None:
678                star = guess_star(repl, variadic=True)
679            if star:
680
681                def transition_function(outcome):
682                    return repl(*outcome)
683            else:
684
685                def transition_function(outcome):
686                    return repl(outcome)
687        else:
688            # repl is a mapping.
689            def transition_function(outcome):
690                if outcome in repl:
691                    return repl[outcome]
692                else:
693                    return outcome
694
695        result: 'Die[tuple[T_co, int]]' = self.map(lambda x: (x, 0))
696
697        def transition_with_steps(outcome_and_steps):
698            outcome, steps = outcome_and_steps
699            next_outcome = transition_function(outcome)
700            if icepool.population.markov_chain.is_absorbing(
701                    outcome, next_outcome):
702                return outcome, steps
703            else:
704                return icepool.tupleize(next_outcome, steps + 1)
705
706        for _ in range(repeat):
707            next_result: 'Die[tuple[T_co, int]]' = icepool.map(
708                transition_with_steps, result)
709            if result == next_result:
710                return next_result
711            result = next_result
712        return result

Maps outcomes of the Die to other outcomes, while also counting timesteps.

This is useful for representing processes.

The outcomes of the result are (outcome, time), where time is the number of repeats needed to reach an absorbing outcome (an outcome that only leads to itself), or repeat, whichever is lesser.

This will return early if it reaches a fixed point. Therefore, you can set repeat equal to the maximum number of time you could possibly be interested in without worrying about it causing extra computations after the fixed point.

EXPERIMENTAL: Again, again_depth, and again_end can be used as the Die() constructor. It is not advised to use these with repeat other than 1.

Arguments:
  • repl: One of the following:
    • A callable returning a new outcome for each old outcome.
    • A mapping from old outcomes to new outcomes. Unmapped old outcomes stay the same. The new outcomes may be dice rather than just single outcomes. The special value icepool.Reroll will reroll that old outcome.
  • star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments before sending them to a callable repl. If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function signature.
  • repeat: This will be repeated with the same arguments on the result this many times.
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
Returns:

The Die after the modification.

def explode( self, which: Union[Callable[..., bool], Collection[+T_co], NoneType] = None, *, star: bool | None = None, depth: int = 9, end=None) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
714    def explode(self,
715                which: Collection[T_co] | Callable[..., bool] | None = None,
716                *,
717                star: bool | None = None,
718                depth: int = 9,
719                end=None) -> 'Die[T_co]':
720        """Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.
721
722        Args:
723            which: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
724                * A single outcome to explode.
725                * An collection of outcomes to explode.
726                * A callable that takes an outcome and returns `True` if it
727                    should be exploded.
728                * If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
729            star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments
730                before sending them to a callable `which`.
731                If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function
732                signature.
733            depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll.
734                If not supplied, a default value will be used.
735            end: Once depth is reached, further explosions will be treated
736                as this value. By default, a zero value will be used.
737        """
738
739        if which is None:
740            outcome_set = {self.max_outcome()}
741        elif callable(which):
742            if star is None:
743                star = guess_star(which, variadic=True)
744            if star:
745                # Need TypeVarTuple to type-check this.
746                outcome_set = {
747                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes()
748                    if which(*outcome)  # type: ignore
749                }
750            else:
751                outcome_set = {
752                    outcome for outcome in self.outcomes() if which(outcome)
753                }
754        else:
755            if not which:
756                return self
757            outcome_set = set(which)
758
759        if depth < 0:
760            raise ValueError('depth cannot be negative.')
761        elif depth == 0:
762            return self
763
764        def map_final(outcome):
765            if outcome in outcome_set:
766                return outcome + icepool.Again
767            else:
768                return outcome
769
770        return self.map(map_final, again_depth=depth, again_end=end)

Causes outcomes to be rolled again and added to the total.

Arguments:
  • which: Which outcomes to explode. Options:
    • A single outcome to explode.
    • An collection of outcomes to explode.
    • A callable that takes an outcome and returns True if it should be exploded.
    • If not supplied, the max outcome will explode.
  • star: Whether outcomes should be unpacked into separate arguments before sending them to a callable which. If not provided, this will be guessed based on the function signature.
  • depth: The maximum number of additional dice to roll. If not supplied, a default value will be used.
  • end: Once depth is reached, further explosions will be treated as this value. By default, a zero value will be used.
def if_else( self, outcome_if_true: Union[~U, icepool.Die[~U]], outcome_if_false: Union[~U, icepool.Die[~U]], *, again_depth: int = 1, again_end: Union[~U, icepool.Die[~U], icepool.RerollType, NoneType] = None) -> icepool.Die[~U]: 
772    def if_else(
773            self,
774            outcome_if_true: U | 'Die[U]',
775            outcome_if_false: U | 'Die[U]',
776            *,
777            again_depth: int = 1,
778            again_end: 'U | Die[U] | icepool.RerollType | None' = None
779    ) -> 'Die[U]':
780        """Ternary conditional operator.
781
782        This replaces truthy outcomes with the first argument and falsy outcomes
783        with the second argument.
784
785        Args:
786            again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
787            again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
788        """
789        return self.map(lambda x: bool(x)).map(
790            {
791                True: outcome_if_true,
792                False: outcome_if_false
793            },
794            again_depth=again_depth,
795            again_end=again_end)

Ternary conditional operator.

This replaces truthy outcomes with the first argument and falsy outcomes with the second argument.

Arguments:
  • again_depth: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
  • again_end: Forwarded to the final die constructor.
def is_in(self, target: Container[+T_co], /) -> icepool.Die[bool]: 
797    def is_in(self, target: Container[T_co], /) -> 'Die[bool]':
798        """A die that returns True iff the roll of the die is contained in the target."""
799        return self.map(lambda x: x in target)

A die that returns True iff the roll of the die is contained in the target.

def count( self, rolls: int, target: Container[+T_co], /) -> icepool.Die[int]: 
801    def count(self, rolls: int, target: Container[T_co], /) -> 'Die[int]':
802        """Roll this dice a number of times and count how many are in the target."""
803        return rolls @ self.is_in(target)

Roll this dice a number of times and count how many are in the target.

def pool( self, rolls: Union[int, Sequence[int]], /) -> icepool.Pool[+T_co]: 
858    def pool(self, rolls: int | Sequence[int], /) -> 'icepool.Pool[T_co]':
859        """Creates a `Pool` from this `Die`.
860
861        You might subscript the pool immediately afterwards, e.g.
862        `d6.pool(5)[-1, ..., 1]` takes the difference between the highest and
863        lowest of 5d6.
864
865        Args:
866            rolls: The number of copies of this `Die` to put in the pool.
867                Or, a sequence of one `int` per die acting as
868                `keep_tuple`. Note that `...` cannot be used in the
869                argument to this method, as the argument determines the size of
870                the pool.
871        """
872        if isinstance(rolls, int):
873            return icepool.Pool({self: rolls})
874        else:
875            pool_size = len(rolls)
876            return icepool.Pool({self: pool_size})[rolls]

Creates a Pool from this Die.

You might subscript the pool immediately afterwards, e.g. d6.pool(5)[-1, ..., 1] takes the difference between the highest and lowest of 5d6.

Arguments:
  • rolls: The number of copies of this Die to put in the pool. Or, a sequence of one int per die acting as keep_tuple. Note that ... cannot be used in the argument to this method, as the argument determines the size of the pool.
def lowest( self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> icepool.Die: 
878    def lowest(self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> 'Die':
879        """Roll several of this `Die` and return the lowest result, or the sum of some of the lowest.
880
881        The outcomes should support addition and multiplication if `keep != 1`.
882
883        Args:
884            rolls: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same
885                outcomes as `self`.
886            keep: The number of dice to keep.
887            drop: If provided, this many lowest dice will be dropped before
888                keeping.
889
890        Returns:
891            A `Die` representing the probability distribution of the sum.
892        """
893        if keep == 1 and drop == 0:
894            return self._lowest_single(rolls)
895
896        start = drop if drop > 0 else None
897        stop = keep + (drop or 0)
898        index = slice(start, stop)
899        # Expression evaluators are difficult to type.
900        return self.pool(rolls)[index].sum()  # type: ignore

Roll several of this Die and return the lowest result, or the sum of some of the lowest.

The outcomes should support addition and multiplication if keep != 1.

Arguments:
  • rolls: The number of dice to roll. All dice will have the same outcomes as self.
  • keep: The number of dice to keep.
  • drop: If provided, this many lowest dice will be dropped before keeping.
Returns:

A Die representing the probability distribution of the sum.

def highest( self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, drop: int = 0) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
910    def highest(self,
911                rolls: int,
912                /,
913                keep: int = 1,
914                drop: int = 0) -> 'Die[T_co]':
915        """Roll several of this `Die` and return the highest result, or the sum of some of the highest.
916
917        The outcomes should support addition and multiplication if `keep != 1`.
918
919        Args:
920            rolls: The number of dice to roll.
921            keep: The number of dice to keep.
922            drop: If provided, this many highest dice will be dropped before
923                keeping.
924
925        Returns:
926            A `Die` representing the probability distribution of the sum.
927        """
928        if keep == 1 and drop == 0:
929            return self._highest_single(rolls)
930        start = -(keep + (drop or 0))
931        stop = -drop if drop > 0 else None
932        index = slice(start, stop)
933        # Expression evaluators are difficult to type.
934        return self.pool(rolls)[index].sum()  # type: ignore

Roll several of this Die and return the highest result, or the sum of some of the highest.

The outcomes should support addition and multiplication if keep != 1.

Arguments:
  • rolls: The number of dice to roll.
  • keep: The number of dice to keep.
  • drop: If provided, this many highest dice will be dropped before keeping.
Returns:

A Die representing the probability distribution of the sum.

def middle( self, rolls: int, /, keep: int = 1, *, tie: Literal['error', 'high', 'low'] = 'error') -> icepool.Die: 
943    def middle(self,
944               rolls: int,
945               /,
946               keep: int = 1,
947               *,
948               tie: Literal['error', 'high', 'low'] = 'error') -> 'icepool.Die':
949        """Roll several of this `Die` and sum the sorted results in the middle.
950
951        The outcomes should support addition and multiplication if `keep != 1`.
952
953        Args:
954            rolls: The number of dice to roll.
955            keep: The number of outcomes to sum. If this is greater than the
956                current keep_size, all are kept.
957            tie: What to do if `keep` is odd but the current keep_size
958                is even, or vice versa.
959                * 'error' (default): Raises `IndexError`.
960                * 'high': The higher outcome is taken.
961                * 'low': The lower outcome is taken.
962        """
963        # Expression evaluators are difficult to type.
964        return self.pool(rolls).middle(keep, tie=tie).sum()  # type: ignore

Roll several of this Die and sum the sorted results in the middle.

The outcomes should support addition and multiplication if keep != 1.

Arguments:
  • rolls: The number of dice to roll.
  • keep: The number of outcomes to sum. If this is greater than the current keep_size, all are kept.
  • tie: What to do if keep is odd but the current keep_size is even, or vice versa.
    • 'error' (default): Raises IndexError.
    • 'high': The higher outcome is taken.
    • 'low': The lower outcome is taken.
def abs(self) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
977    def abs(self) -> 'Die[T_co]':
978        return self.unary_operator(operator.abs)
def round(self, ndigits: int | None = None) -> icepool.Die: 
982    def round(self, ndigits: int | None = None) -> 'Die':
983        return self.unary_operator(round, ndigits)
def trunc(self) -> icepool.Die: 
987    def trunc(self) -> 'Die':
988        return self.unary_operator(math.trunc)
def floor(self) -> icepool.Die: 
992    def floor(self) -> 'Die':
993        return self.unary_operator(math.floor)
def ceil(self) -> icepool.Die: 
997    def ceil(self) -> 'Die':
998        return self.unary_operator(math.ceil)
def zero(self) -> icepool.Die[+T_co]: 
1006    def zero(self) -> 'Die[T_co]':
1007        """Zeros all outcomes of this die.
1008
1009        This is done by multiplying all outcomes by `0`.
1010
1011        The result will have the same denominator as this die.
1012
1013        Raises:
1014            ValueError: If the zeros did not resolve to a single outcome.
1015        """
1016        result = self.unary_operator(Die._zero)
1017        if len(result) != 1:
1018            raise ValueError('zero() did not resolve to a single outcome.')
1019        return result

Zeros all outcomes of this die.

This is done by multiplying all outcomes by 0.

The result will have the same denominator as this die.

Raises:
  • ValueError: If the zeros did not resolve to a single outcome.
def zero_outcome(self) -> +T_co: 
1021    def zero_outcome(self) -> T_co:
1022        """A zero-outcome for this die.
1023
1024        E.g. `0` for a `Die` whose outcomes are `int`s.
1025        """
1026        return self.zero().outcomes()[0]

A zero-outcome for this die.

E.g. 0 for a Die whose outcomes are ints.

def cmp(self, other) -> icepool.Die[int]: 
1218    def cmp(self, other) -> 'Die[int]':
1219        """A `Die` with outcomes 1, -1, and 0.
1220
1221        The quantities are equal to the positive outcome of `self > other`,
1222        `self < other`, and the remainder respectively.
1223
1224        This will include all three outcomes even if they have zero quantity.
1225        """
1226        other = implicit_convert_to_die(other)
1227
1228        data = {}
1229
1230        lt = self < other
1231        if True in lt:
1232            data[-1] = lt[True]
1233        eq = self == other
1234        if True in eq:
1235            data[0] = eq[True]
1236        gt = self > other
1237        if True in gt:
1238            data[1] = gt[True]
1239
1240        return Die(data)

A Die with outcomes 1, -1, and 0.

The quantities are equal to the positive outcome of self > other, self < other, and the remainder respectively.

This will include all three outcomes even if they have zero quantity.

def sign(self) -> icepool.Die[int]: 
1252    def sign(self) -> 'Die[int]':
1253        """Outcomes become 1 if greater than `zero()`, -1 if less than `zero()`, and 0 otherwise.
1254
1255        Note that for `float`s, +0.0, -0.0, and nan all become 0.
1256        """
1257        return self.unary_operator(Die._sign)

Outcomes become 1 if greater than zero(), -1 if less than zero(), and 0 otherwise.

Note that for floats, +0.0, -0.0, and nan all become 0.

def equals(self, other, *, simplify: bool = False) -> bool: 
1283    def equals(self, other, *, simplify: bool = False) -> bool:
1284        """`True` iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.
1285
1286        This is `False` if `other` is not a `Die`, even if it would convert
1287        to an equal `Die`.
1288
1289        Truth value does NOT matter.
1290
1291        If one `Die` has a zero-quantity outcome and the other `Die` does not
1292        contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.
1293
1294        The `==` and `!=` operators have a dual purpose; they return a `Die`
1295        with a truth value determined by this method.
1296        Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of
1297        these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested
1298        in the `Die` value or the truth value.
1299
1300        Args:
1301            simplify: If `True`, the dice will be simplified before comparing.
1302                Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not `equals()` to a 1:1 coin.
1303        """
1304        if not isinstance(other, Die):
1305            return False
1306
1307        if simplify:
1308            return self.simplify()._key_tuple == other.simplify()._key_tuple
1309        else:
1310            return self._key_tuple == other._key_tuple

True iff both dice have the same outcomes and quantities.

This is False if other is not a Die, even if it would convert to an equal Die.

Truth value does NOT matter.

If one Die has a zero-quantity outcome and the other Die does not contain that outcome, they are treated as unequal by this function.

The == and != operators have a dual purpose; they return a Die with a truth value determined by this method. Only dice returned by these methods have a truth value. The data of these dice is lazily evaluated since the caller may only be interested in the Die value or the truth value.

Arguments:
  • simplify: If True, the dice will be simplified before comparing. Otherwise, e.g. a 2:2 coin is not equals() to a 1:1 coin.

collections.abc.Mapping
get
class Population(abc.ABC, typing.Generic[+T_co], typing.Mapping[typing.Any, int]): 
 25class Population(ABC, Generic[T_co], Mapping[Any, int]):
 26    """A mapping from outcomes to `int` quantities.
 27
 28    Outcomes with each instance must be hashable and totally orderable.
 29
 30    Subclasses include `Die` and `Deck`.
 31    """
 32
 33    # Abstract methods.
 34
 35    @property
 36    @abstractmethod
 37    def _new_type(self) -> type:
 38        """The type to use when constructing a new instance."""
 39
 40    @abstractmethod
 41    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView[T_co]:
 42        """The outcomes within the population in sorted order."""
 43
 44    @abstractmethod
 45    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
 46        """The quantities within the population in outcome order."""
 47
 48    @abstractmethod
 49    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView[T_co]:
 50        """The (outcome, quantity)s of the population in sorted order."""
 51
 52    def _unary_operator(self, op: Callable[..., U], *args, **kwargs):
 53        data: MutableMapping[Any, int] = defaultdict(int)
 54        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
 55            new_outcome = op(outcome, *args, **kwargs)
 56            data[new_outcome] += quantity
 57        return self._new_type(data)
 58
 59    # Outcomes.
 60
 61    def outcomes(self) -> CountsKeysView[T_co]:
 62        """The sorted outcomes of the mapping.
 63
 64        These are also the `keys` of the mapping.
 65        Prefer to use the name `outcomes`.
 66        """
 67        return self.keys()
 68
 69    @cached_property
 70    def _common_outcome_length(self) -> int | None:
 71        result = None
 72        for outcome in self.outcomes():
 73            if isinstance(outcome, Sized):
 74                if result is None:
 75                    result = len(outcome)
 76                elif len(outcome) != result:
 77                    return None
 78        return result
 79
 80    def common_outcome_length(self) -> int | None:
 81        """The common length of all outcomes.
 82
 83        If outcomes have no lengths or different lengths, the result is `None`.
 84        """
 85        return self._common_outcome_length
 86
 87    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
 88        """`True` iff this population has no outcomes. """
 89        return len(self) == 0
 90
 91    def min_outcome(self) -> T_co:
 92        """The least outcome."""
 93        return self.outcomes()[0]
 94
 95    def max_outcome(self) -> T_co:
 96        """The greatest outcome."""
 97        return self.outcomes()[-1]
 98
 99    def nearest_le(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
100        """The nearest outcome that is <= the argument.
101
102        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
103        """
104        if outcome in self:
105            return outcome
106        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
107        if index < 0:
108            return None
109        return self.outcomes()[index]
110
111    def nearest_lt(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
112        """The nearest outcome that is < the argument.
113
114        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
115        """
116        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
117        if index < 0:
118            return None
119        return self.outcomes()[index]
120
121    def nearest_ge(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
122        """The nearest outcome that is >= the argument.
123
124        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
125        """
126        if outcome in self:
127            return outcome
128        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
129        if index >= len(self):
130            return None
131        return self.outcomes()[index]
132
133    def nearest_gt(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
134        """The nearest outcome that is > the argument.
135
136        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
137        """
138        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome)
139        if index >= len(self):
140            return None
141        return self.outcomes()[index]
142
143    # Quantities.
144
145    def quantity(self, outcome: Hashable) -> int:
146        """The quantity of a single outcome, or 0 if not present."""
147        return self.get(outcome, 0)
148
149    @overload
150    def quantities(self) -> CountsValuesView:
151        ...
152
153    @overload
154    def quantities(self, outcomes: Sequence) -> Sequence[int]:
155        ...
156
157    def quantities(
158            self,
159            outcomes: Sequence | None = None
160    ) -> CountsValuesView | Sequence[int]:
161        """The quantities of the mapping in sorted order.
162
163        These are also the `values` of the mapping.
164        Prefer to use the name `quantities`.
165
166        Args:
167            outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these
168                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
169        """
170        if outcomes is None:
171            return self.values()
172        else:
173            return tuple(self.quantity(outcome) for outcome in outcomes)
174
175    @cached_property
176    def _denominator(self) -> int:
177        return sum(self.values())
178
179    def denominator(self) -> int:
180        """The sum of all quantities (e.g. weights or duplicates).
181
182        For the number of unique outcomes, including those with zero quantity,
183        use `len()`.
184        """
185        return self._denominator
186
187    # Quantities.
188
189    def scale_quantities(self: C, scale: int) -> C:
190        """Scales all quantities by an integer."""
191        if scale == 1:
192            return self
193        data = {outcome: quantity * scale for outcome, quantity in self.items()}
194        return self._new_type(data)
195
196    def has_zero_quantities(self) -> bool:
197        """`True` iff `self` contains at least one outcome with zero quantity. """
198        return 0 in self.values()
199
200    def quantity_ne(self, outcome) -> int:
201        """The quantity != a single outcome. """
202        return self.denominator() - self.quantity(outcome)
203
204    @cached_property
205    def _cumulative_quantities(self) -> Mapping[T_co, int]:
206        result = {}
207        cdf = 0
208        for outcome, quantity in self.items():
209            cdf += quantity
210            result[outcome] = cdf
211        return result
212
213    def quantity_le(self, outcome) -> int:
214        """The quantity <= a single outcome."""
215        outcome = self.nearest_le(outcome)
216        if outcome is None:
217            return 0
218        else:
219            return self._cumulative_quantities[outcome]
220
221    def quantity_lt(self, outcome) -> int:
222        """The quantity < a single outcome."""
223        outcome = self.nearest_lt(outcome)
224        if outcome is None:
225            return 0
226        else:
227            return self._cumulative_quantities[outcome]
228
229    def quantity_ge(self, outcome) -> int:
230        """The quantity >= a single outcome."""
231        return self.denominator() - self.quantity_lt(outcome)
232
233    def quantity_gt(self, outcome) -> int:
234        """The quantity > a single outcome."""
235        return self.denominator() - self.quantity_le(outcome)
236
237    @cached_property
238    def _quantities_le(self) -> Sequence[int]:
239        return tuple(itertools.accumulate(self.values()))
240
241    def quantities_le(self, outcomes: Sequence | None = None) -> Sequence[int]:
242        """The quantity <= each outcome in order.
243
244        Args:
245            outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these
246                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
247        """
248        if outcomes is None:
249            return self._quantities_le
250        else:
251            return tuple(self.quantity_le(x) for x in outcomes)
252
253    @cached_property
254    def _quantities_ge(self) -> Sequence[int]:
255        return tuple(
256            itertools.accumulate(self.values()[:-1],
257                                 operator.sub,
258                                 initial=self.denominator()))
259
260    def quantities_ge(self, outcomes: Sequence | None = None) -> Sequence[int]:
261        """The quantity >= each outcome in order.
262
263        Args:
264            outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these
265                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
266        """
267        if outcomes is None:
268            return self._quantities_ge
269        else:
270            return tuple(self.quantity_ge(x) for x in outcomes)
271
272    def quantities_lt(self, outcomes: Sequence | None = None) -> Sequence[int]:
273        """The quantity < each outcome in order.
274
275        Args:
276            outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these
277                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
278        """
279        return tuple(
280            self.denominator() - x for x in self.quantities_ge(outcomes))
281
282    def quantities_gt(self, outcomes: Sequence | None = None) -> Sequence[int]:
283        """The quantity > each outcome in order.
284
285        Args:
286            outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these
287                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
288        """
289        return tuple(
290            self.denominator() - x for x in self.quantities_le(outcomes))
291
292    # Probabilities.
293
294    def probability(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float:
295        """The probability of a single outcome, or 0.0 if not present. """
296        return self.quantity(outcome) / self.denominator()
297
298    def probability_le(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float:
299        """The probability <= a single outcome. """
300        return self.quantity_le(outcome) / self.denominator()
301
302    def probability_lt(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float:
303        """The probability < a single outcome. """
304        return self.quantity_lt(outcome) / self.denominator()
305
306    def probability_ge(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float:
307        """The probability >= a single outcome. """
308        return self.quantity_ge(outcome) / self.denominator()
309
310    def probability_gt(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float:
311        """The probability > a single outcome. """
312        return self.quantity_gt(outcome) / self.denominator()
313
314    @cached_property
315    def _probabilities(self) -> Sequence[float]:
316        return tuple(v / self.denominator() for v in self.values())
317
318    def probabilities(self,
319                      outcomes: Sequence | None = None,
320                      *,
321                      percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
322        """The probability of each outcome in order.
323
324        Also known as the probability mass function (PMF).
325
326        Args:
327            outcomes: If provided, the probabilities corresponding to these
328                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
329            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
330                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
331        """
332        if outcomes is None:
333            result = self._probabilities
334        else:
335            result = tuple(self.probability(x) for x in outcomes)
336
337        if percent:
338            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in result)
339        else:
340            return result
341
342    @cached_property
343    def _probabilities_le(self) -> Sequence[float]:
344        return tuple(
345            quantity / self.denominator() for quantity in self.quantities_le())
346
347    def probabilities_le(self,
348                         outcomes: Sequence | None = None,
349                         *,
350                         percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
351        """The probability of rolling <= each outcome in order.
352
353        Also known as the cumulative distribution function (CDF),
354        though this term is ambigiuous whether it is < or <=.
355
356        Args:
357            outcomes: If provided, the probabilities corresponding to these
358                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
359            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
360                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
361        """
362        if outcomes is None:
363            result = self._probabilities_le
364        else:
365            result = tuple(self.probability_le(x) for x in outcomes)
366
367        if percent:
368            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in result)
369        else:
370            return result
371
372    @cached_property
373    def _probabilities_ge(self) -> Sequence[float]:
374        return tuple(
375            quantity / self.denominator() for quantity in self.quantities_ge())
376
377    def probabilities_ge(self,
378                         outcomes: Sequence | None = None,
379                         *,
380                         percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
381        """The probability of rolling >= each outcome in order.
382
383        Also known as the survival function (SF) or
384        complementary cumulative distribution function (CCDF),
385        though these term are ambigiuous whether they are is > or >=.
386
387        Args:
388            outcomes: If provided, the probabilities corresponding to these
389                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
390            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
391                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
392        """
393        if outcomes is None:
394            result = self._probabilities_ge
395        else:
396            result = tuple(self.probability_ge(x) for x in outcomes)
397
398        if percent:
399            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in result)
400        else:
401            return result
402
403    def probabilities_lt(self,
404                         outcomes: Sequence | None = None,
405                         *,
406                         percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
407        """The probability of rolling < each outcome in order.
408
409        Args:
410            outcomes: If provided, the probabilities corresponding to these
411                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
412            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
413                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
414        """
415        if outcomes is None:
416            result = tuple(1.0 - x for x in self._probabilities_ge)
417        else:
418            result = tuple(1.0 - self.probability_ge(x) for x in outcomes)
419
420        if percent:
421            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in result)
422        else:
423            return result
424
425    def probabilities_gt(self,
426                         outcomes: Sequence | None = None,
427                         *,
428                         percent: bool = False) -> Sequence[float]:
429        """The probability of rolling > each outcome in order.
430
431        Args:
432            outcomes: If provided, the probabilities corresponding to these
433                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
434            percent: If set, the results will be in percent (i.e. total of 100.0).
435                Otherwise, the total will be 1.0.
436        """
437        if outcomes is None:
438            result = tuple(1.0 - x for x in self._probabilities_le)
439        else:
440            result = tuple(1.0 - self.probability_le(x) for x in outcomes)
441
442        if percent:
443            return tuple(100.0 * x for x in result)
444        else:
445            return result
446
447    # Scalar statistics.
448
449    def mode(self) -> tuple:
450        """A tuple containing the most common outcome(s) of the population.
451
452        These are sorted from lowest to highest.
453        """
454        return tuple(outcome for outcome, quantity in self.items()
455                     if quantity == self.modal_quantity())
456
457    def modal_quantity(self) -> int:
458        """The highest quantity of any single outcome. """
459        return max(self.quantities())
460
461    def kolmogorov_smirnov(self, other) -> float:
462        """KolmogorovSmirnov statistic. The maximum absolute difference between CDFs. """
463        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
464        return max(
465            abs(a - b)
466            for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))
467
468    def cramer_von_mises(self, other) -> float:
469        """Cramr-von Mises statistic. The sum-of-squares difference between CDFs. """
470        a, b = icepool.align(self, other)
471        return sum((a - b)**2
472                   for a, b in zip(a.probabilities_le(), b.probabilities_le()))
473
474    def median(self):
475        """The median, taking the mean in case of a tie.
476
477        This will fail if the outcomes do not support division;
478        in this case, use `median_low` or `median_high` instead.
479        """
480        return self.quantile(1, 2)
481
482    def median_low(self) -> T_co:
483        """The median, taking the lower in case of a tie."""
484        return self.quantile_low(1, 2)
485
486    def median_high(self) -> T_co:
487        """The median, taking the higher in case of a tie."""
488        return self.quantile_high(1, 2)
489
490    def quantile(self, n: int, d: int = 100):
491        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the mean in case of a tie.
492
493        This will fail if the outcomes do not support addition and division;
494        in this case, use `quantile_low` or `quantile_high` instead.
495        """
496        # Should support addition and division.
497        return (self.quantile_low(n, d) +
498                self.quantile_high(n, d)) / 2  # type: ignore
499
500    def quantile_low(self, n: int, d: int = 100) -> T_co:
501        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the lesser in case of a tie."""
502        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.quantities_le(),
503                                   (n * self.denominator() + d - 1) // d)
504        if index >= len(self):
505            return self.max_outcome()
506        return self.outcomes()[index]
507
508    def quantile_high(self, n: int, d: int = 100) -> T_co:
509        """The outcome `n / d` of the way through the CDF, taking the greater in case of a tie."""
510        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(),
511                                    n * self.denominator() // d)
512        if index >= len(self):
513            return self.max_outcome()
514        return self.outcomes()[index]
515
516    def mean(self: 'Population[numbers.Real]') -> float:
517        return sum(outcome * quantity
518                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
519
520    def variance(self: 'Population[numbers.Real]') -> float:
521        """This is the population variance, not the sample variance."""
522        mean = self.mean()
523        mean_of_squares = sum(
524            quantity * outcome**2
525            for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
526        return mean_of_squares - mean * mean
527
528    def standard_deviation(self: 'Population[numbers.Real]') -> float:
529        return math.sqrt(self.variance())
530
531    sd = standard_deviation
532
533    def standardized_moment(self: 'Population[numbers.Real]', k: int) -> float:
534        sd = self.standard_deviation()
535        mean = self.mean()
536        ev = sum(p * (outcome - mean)**k
537                 for outcome, p in zip(self.outcomes(), self.probabilities()))
538        return ev / (sd**k)
539
540    def skewness(self: 'Population[numbers.Real]') -> float:
541        return self.standardized_moment(3)
542
543    def excess_kurtosis(self: 'Population[numbers.Real]') -> float:
544        return self.standardized_moment(4) - 3.0
545
546    # Joint statistics.
547
548    class _Marginals(Sequence):
549        """Helper class for implementing `marginals()`."""
550
551        def __init__(self, population, /):
552            self._population = population
553
554        def __len__(self) -> int:
555            """The minimum len() of all outcomes."""
556            return min(len(x) for x in self._population.outcomes())
557
558        def __getitem__(self, dims: int | slice, /):
559            """Marginalizes the given dimensions."""
560            return self._population._unary_operator(operator.getitem, dims)
561
562    @property
563    def marginals(self):
564        """A property that applies the `[]` operator to outcomes.
565
566        For example, `population.marginals[:2]` will marginalize the first two
567        elements of the outcomes.
568        """
569        return Population._Marginals(self)
570
571    def covariance(self: 'Population[tuple[numbers.Real, ...]]', i: int,
572                   j: int) -> float:
573        mean_i = self.marginals[i].mean()
574        mean_j = self.marginals[j].mean()
575        return sum((outcome[i] - mean_i) * (outcome[j] - mean_j) * quantity
576                   for outcome, quantity in self.items()) / self.denominator()
577
578    def correlation(self: 'Population[tuple[numbers.Real, ...]]', i: int,
579                    j: int) -> float:
580        sd_i = self.marginals[i].standard_deviation()
581        sd_j = self.marginals[j].standard_deviation()
582        return self.covariance(i, j) / (sd_i * sd_j)
583
584    def sample(self) -> T_co:
585        """A single random sample from this population.
586
587        Note that this is always "with replacement" even for `Deck` since
588        instances are immutable.
589
590        This uses the standard `random` package and is not cryptographically
591        secure.
592        """
593        # We don't use random.choices since that is based on floats rather than ints.
594        r = random.randrange(self.denominator())
595        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.quantities_le(), r)
596        return self.outcomes()[index]
597
598    def format(self, format_spec: str, /, **kwargs) -> str:
599        """Formats this mapping as a string.
600
601        `format_spec` should start with the output format,
602        which can be:
603        * `md` for Markdown (default)
604        * `bbcode` for BBCode
605        * `csv` for comma-separated values
606        * `html` for HTML
607
608        After this, you may optionally add a `:` followed by a series of
609        requested columns. Allowed columns are:
610
611        * `o`: Outcomes.
612        * `*o`: Outcomes, unpacked if applicable.
613        * `q==`, `q<=`, `q>=`: Quantities ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
614        * `p==`, `p<=`, `p>=`: Probabilities (0-1) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
615        * `%==`, `%<=`, `%>=`: Probabilities (0%-100%) ==, <=, or >= each outcome.
616
617        Columns may optionally be separated using `|` characters.
618
619        The default columns are `*o|q==|%==`, which are the unpacked outcomes,
620        the quantities, and the probabilities. The quantities are omitted from
621        the default columns if any individual quantity is 10**30 or greater.
622        """
623        if not self.is_empty() and self.modal_quantity() < 10**30:
624            default_column_spec = '*oq==%=='
625        else:
626            default_column_spec = '*o%=='
627        if len(format_spec) == 0:
628            format_spec = 'md:' + default_column_spec
629
630        format_spec = format_spec.replace('|', '')
631
632        parts = format_spec.split(':')
633
634        if len(parts) == 1:
635            output_format = parts[0]
636            col_spec = default_column_spec
637        elif len(parts) == 2:
638            output_format = parts[0]
639            col_spec = parts[1]
640        else:
641            raise ValueError('format_spec has too many colons.')
642
643        if output_format == 'md':
644            return icepool.population.format.markdown(self, col_spec)
645        elif output_format == 'bbcode':
646            return icepool.population.format.bbcode(self, col_spec)
647        elif output_format == 'csv':
648            return icepool.population.format.csv(self, col_spec, **kwargs)
649        elif output_format == 'html':
650            return icepool.population.format.html(self, col_spec)
651        else:
652            raise ValueError(f"Unsupported output format '{output_format}'")
653
654    def __format__(self, format_spec: str, /) -> str:
655        return self.format(format_spec)
656
657    def __str__(self) -> str:
658        return f'{self}'

A mapping from outcomes to int quantities.

Outcomes with each instance must be hashable and totally orderable.

Subclasses include Die and Deck.

@abstractmethod
def keys(self) -> icepool.CountsKeysView[+T_co]: 
40    @abstractmethod
41    def keys(self) -> CountsKeysView[T_co]:
42        """The outcomes within the population in sorted order."""

The outcomes within the population in sorted order.

@abstractmethod
def values(self) -> icepool.CountsValuesView: 
44    @abstractmethod
45    def values(self) -> CountsValuesView:
46        """The quantities within the population in outcome order."""

The quantities within the population in outcome order.

@abstractmethod
def items(self) -> icepool.CountsItemsView[+T_co]: 
48    @abstractmethod
49    def items(self) -> CountsItemsView[T_co]:
50        """The (outcome, quantity)s of the population in sorted order."""

The (outcome, quantity)s of the population in sorted order.

def outcomes(self) -> icepool.CountsKeysView[+T_co]: 
61    def outcomes(self) -> CountsKeysView[T_co]:
62        """The sorted outcomes of the mapping.
63
64        These are also the `keys` of the mapping.
65        Prefer to use the name `outcomes`.
66        """
67        return self.keys()

The sorted outcomes of the mapping.

These are also the keys of the mapping. Prefer to use the name outcomes.

def common_outcome_length(self) -> int | None: 
80    def common_outcome_length(self) -> int | None:
81        """The common length of all outcomes.
82
83        If outcomes have no lengths or different lengths, the result is `None`.
84        """
85        return self._common_outcome_length

The common length of all outcomes.

If outcomes have no lengths or different lengths, the result is None.

def is_empty(self) -> bool: 
87    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
88        """`True` iff this population has no outcomes. """
89        return len(self) == 0

True iff this population has no outcomes.

def min_outcome(self) -> +T_co: 
91    def min_outcome(self) -> T_co:
92        """The least outcome."""
93        return self.outcomes()[0]

The least outcome.

def max_outcome(self) -> +T_co: 
95    def max_outcome(self) -> T_co:
96        """The greatest outcome."""
97        return self.outcomes()[-1]

The greatest outcome.

def nearest_le(self, outcome) -> Optional[+T_co]: 
 99    def nearest_le(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
100        """The nearest outcome that is <= the argument.
101
102        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
103        """
104        if outcome in self:
105            return outcome
106        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
107        if index < 0:
108            return None
109        return self.outcomes()[index]

The nearest outcome that is <= the argument.

Returns None if there is no such outcome.

def nearest_lt(self, outcome) -> Optional[+T_co]: 
111    def nearest_lt(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
112        """The nearest outcome that is < the argument.
113
114        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
115        """
116        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome) - 1
117        if index < 0:
118            return None
119        return self.outcomes()[index]

The nearest outcome that is < the argument.

Returns None if there is no such outcome.

def nearest_ge(self, outcome) -> Optional[+T_co]: 
121    def nearest_ge(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
122        """The nearest outcome that is >= the argument.
123
124        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
125        """
126        if outcome in self:
127            return outcome
128        index = bisect.bisect_left(self.outcomes(), outcome)
129        if index >= len(self):
130            return None
131        return self.outcomes()[index]

The nearest outcome that is >= the argument.

Returns None if there is no such outcome.

def nearest_gt(self, outcome) -> Optional[+T_co]: 
133    def nearest_gt(self, outcome) -> T_co | None:
134        """The nearest outcome that is > the argument.
135
136        Returns `None` if there is no such outcome.
137        """
138        index = bisect.bisect_right(self.outcomes(), outcome)
139        if index >= len(self):
140            return None
141        return self.outcomes()[index]

The nearest outcome that is > the argument.

Returns None if there is no such outcome.

def quantity(self, outcome: Hashable) -> int: 
145    def quantity(self, outcome: Hashable) -> int:
146        """The quantity of a single outcome, or 0 if not present."""
147        return self.get(outcome, 0)

The quantity of a single outcome, or 0 if not present.

def quantities( self, outcomes: Optional[Sequence] = None) -> Union[icepool.CountsValuesView, Sequence[int]]: 
157    def quantities(
158            self,
159            outcomes: Sequence | None = None
160    ) -> CountsValuesView | Sequence[int]:
161        """The quantities of the mapping in sorted order.
162
163        These are also the `values` of the mapping.
164        Prefer to use the name `quantities`.
165
166        Args:
167            outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these
168                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
169        """
170        if outcomes is None:
171            return self.values()
172        else:
173            return tuple(self.quantity(outcome) for outcome in outcomes)

The quantities of the mapping in sorted order.

These are also the values of the mapping. Prefer to use the name quantities.

Arguments:
  • outcomes: If provided, the quantities corresponding to these outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).
def denominator(self) -> int: 
179    def denominator(self) -> int:
180        """The sum of all quantities (e.g. weights or duplicates).
181
182        For the number of unique outcomes, including those with zero quantity,
183        use `len()`.
184        """
185        return self._denominator

The sum of all quantities (e.g. weights or duplicates).

For the number of unique outcomes, including those with zero quantity, use len().

def scale_quantities(self: ~C, scale: int) -> ~C: 
189    def scale_quantities(self: C, scale: int) -> C:
190        """Scales all quantities by an integer."""
191        if scale == 1:
192            return self
193        data = {outcome: quantity * scale for outcome, quantity in self.items()}
194        return self._new_type(data)

Scales all quantities by an integer.

def has_zero_quantities(self) -> bool: 
196    def has_zero_quantities(self) -> bool:
197        """`True` iff `self` contains at least one outcome with zero quantity. """
198        return 0 in self.values()

True iff self contains at least one outcome with zero quantity.

def quantity_ne(self, outcome) -> int: 
200    def quantity_ne(self, outcome) -> int:
201        """The quantity != a single outcome. """
202        return self.denominator() - self.quantity(outcome)

The quantity != a single outcome.

def quantity_le(self, outcome) -> int: 
213    def quantity_le(self, outcome) -> int:
214        """The quantity <= a single outcome."""
215        outcome = self.nearest_le(outcome)
216        if outcome is None:
217            return 0
218        else:
219            return self._cumulative_quantities[outcome]

The quantity <= a single outcome.

def quantity_lt(self, outcome) -> int:

222        """The quantity < a single outcome."""

224        if outcome is None:
225            return 0
226        else:
227            return self._cumulative_quantities[outcome]

230        """The quantity >= a single outcome."""

234        """The quantity > a single outcome."""

243

246                outcomes will be returned (or 0 if not present).

def probability(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float: 
294    def probability(self, outcome: Hashable) -> float:
295        """The probability of a single outcome, or 0.0 if not present. """
296        return self.quantity(outcome) / self.denominator()
